etymologies: mid 19th century; earliest use found in The North American Review. From pass + man

definitions: At Oxford and Cambridge Universities: a (male) student who reads for and takes a pass degree, as opposed to an honours degree; a student who passes a degree without attaining honours. Compare honour man; "class-man". Compare also "pass-woman".
A male prisoner who is allowed to leave his cell as a special privilege, especially in order to perform certain duties.
